song.comment: Collected by Bob Copper in about 1954 from Jim Barrett, at the Fox in North Waltham, Hants

verse.name: v1
verse.lines: At Manchester City the sign of the Plough, There lives an old molecatcher, I can't tell you how. He goes a-molecatching from morning till night While the jolly young farmer goes playing with his wife.

verse.name: v2
verse.lines: The molecatcher jealous of the very same thing, So he hides in the bake-house and saw him come in, And when that young farmer got over the stile It caused the molecatcher to laugh and to smile.

verse.name: v3
verse.lines: He knocked at the door and thus he did say, Pray, where is your husband, good woman, I say. He's gone a-molecatching, you need not fear, But little did she think the molecatcher was near.

verse.name: v4
verse.lines: She went upstairs - he followed the sign, And the molecatcher followed them closely behind, And when that young farmer was in the midst of his sport The molecatcher grabbed him quite fast by his coat.

verse.name: v5
verse.lines: He clapped his hands and laughed at the sight, Saying, "This is the finest mole I've catched in me life. I'll make you pay well for ploughing my ground And the money it shall be no less than ten pound."

verse.name: v6
verse.lines: "Very well", said the farmer, "the money I don't mind, For it only costs me about twopence a time." So come all you young farmer chaps, mind what you're at And never get caught in a molecatcher's trap.
